bioghist.p: Robert G. Parr was born in Chicago, Illinois in 1921. He attended Brown University and did his graduate work at the University of Minnesota under Bryce Crawford. He subsequently taught at Carnegie Institute of Technology, Johns Hopkins University and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Robert G. Parr was an important theoretical chemist. In concert with his pupil Rudolph Pariser and in conjunction with the research of Sir John Pople he contributed to the formulation of what came to be called "the P-P-P method" for predicting electronic spectra. In the latter part of his career he devoted his energy to the Density Functional Theory. Robert G. Parr is now retired.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of papers from the career of Robert G. Parr. Materials include: research notes and calculations, correspondence, career records, files on overseas speaking engagements, publications lists, curricula vitae (1975-1998), grant proposals and progress reports, progress and technical reports from projects at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, University of Chicago, and Oxford, documents relating to awards and honors, and records of membership in scientific societies. Some of the research notes relate to his work on the Density-Functional Theory, but there are files on many other topics as well.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
